Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research:Extreme Value Theory for Spatially Indexed Functional Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the development of statistical tools to model the spatial and temporal structure of environmental and climate extreme events. Most climate and environmental data sets can be viewed as collections of curves, one curve per year, available at several locations within a region. For example, temperature at a specific location has an annual pattern. The shapes of such annual curves change from year to year, and from location to location. Extreme departures from a typical pattern over a sizeable region can impact agricultural production and public health. The economic impacts are considerable, particularly, if they occur at unexpected times and locations. An unusual timing of a heat wave over a large area may cause significant economic damage due to crop failure and forest fires, and also affect the level of preparedness of public health services. Similarly, long spells of cold, storm-free winter time weather often lead to an increase in particulate pollution levels in densely populated mountain valleys. It is important that public officials are well-informed about the possible range and impact of such extreme events. This project will contribute toward a rigorous and objective understanding of the risks involved, and provide quantitative tools for researchers and decision makers in the fields of agriculture, public health, actuarial science, climatology and ecology.

The project seeks to develop a statistical framework for a quantitative assessment of possible extremal departures from the usual annual pattern over a region, i.e. departures of the form that have not been observed in historical records, but can occur with a positive probability. The primary focus of the project is the creation of a mathematical framework, and implementation through the development of statistical software. Building on recent advances in functional data analysis, extreme value theory and spatio-temporal statistics, methodology for modeling the extremal distributions of curves observed at spatial locations will be developed. Extreme curves will be determined by functionals defined on a function space in which the curves live. The work will be guided and validated by the analysis of several historical, derived, and computer data sets. Exploratory analysis will reveal the most prominent properties of extremal shapes. This will be followed by model building and the development of asymptotic theory needed to evaluate probabilities of events not previously observed. The models will reveal extremal features of the spatially indexed functional data that are not apparent from the exploratory analysis. Procedures for the construction of confidence regions, where extremal departures may occur with prescribed probability, will be obtained. Exploratory and inferential tools for the assessment of trends in the extremal shapes and regions over which they occur will also be derived.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broad objective of the research was to develop statistical models and methods  that would be useful in predicting various aspectsof extreme weather events, as well as of extreme events in otherfields, including public health and finance. The data that motivatedthis research have the form of functions. For example, one can considerfor a  location, like Washington DC, and a  sequence of annual temperaturecurves at this location. For example, if temperature measurementsare  available from 1901 to 2018, then we have a time series 118 curves. There will be analogous sequences of curves, generally of different lengths, at hundreds of other locations in the United States. 


Traditional Extreme Value Theory focuses on the highest (or lowest) temperature in a given year. So with 118 years of measurements, it would study a sequence of 118 numbers. However, there is much more information in the whole annual temperature curves than just the highest temperature in a given year. For example, the highest temperature in a specific year might not be extreme at all, but therecould be an exceptionally long spell of very high temperatures, which could have a more adverse public health impact that just one hot day.The area over which the hot spell extends would also matter. 


Intellectual Merit: 


Our research aimed at developing a statistical framework that would develop quantitative tools for answering questions related to extreme behavior of curves, or other functions, that exhibit dependence in timeand space, or another analogous dimension. We have developed many aspects mathematical theory that allow us to compute probabilities ofvarious extreme events and estimate their characteristics, like the maximalspacial extent. We derived rigorous procedures for verifying if the assumptions needed for the implementation of our methodology aresatisfied. We developed computational and graphical tools needed to represent massive data sets generated by modern climate models. We applied the new approaches to financial data and obtained proceduresfor evaluating the risk of extreme patterns of returns over a trading day. We published over 30 research papers, about 1/3 of them in top statistics journals. 


Broader Impacts: 


The research  will impact climate, public health and agricultural research by providing tools to quantitatively  study extreme weather events that may adversely affect large human or animal populations or crop yields. It will also impact risk assessment of financial operations, and other fields, e.g. hydrology, whereextremely high or low river flows over large parts of a basin and/or long periods are detrimental. In the course of the research the team trained15 PhD students in modern statistical techniques relevant to the solution of problems of important societal impact. Indirectly, our research will help  elected and appointed public officials to make informed decisionsaimed at reducing the impact of undesirable extreme events of various types
